Content.BodyCopy:
Student Technology Center

The Student Technology Center (STC) exists to help students with technological questions and assist students with various technology assignments. To accomplish this task the STC works with the faculty in understanding the technology needs for the various assignments. Then the STC student staff will learn these technologies to become a resource for the faculty in helping the students with their technology assignments. The STC will assist students with I-Learn, photos, video and audio editing, design projects, word processing, presentation, spreadsheets and other academic computer programs and hardware.




Study Skills Center

The Study Skills Center provides free study skills consulting by peer tutors. Students may come here to take an online assessment of their study practices. The assessment identifies where learning breaks down and provides strategies for improvement. Additionally, students may come here to view an array of video mini lessons on variety of topics including how to work in groups, the importance of class attendance, the effects of cramming, strategies for scheduling their studies, etc. These videos may also be viewed from the study skills website.




The Research Center

If you ever have trouble knowing how to research your topic effectively, come to the Research Center. The Learning Commons also provides access to researching resources such as encyclopedias, books, and computers for accessing Refworks and hundreds of online databases. Training is available for those seeking assistance in navigating the online databases and journals.

Ever wondered where faculty could send their students for additional academic assistance? Where your students could go for technology one-on-ones or workshops created to assist faculty by supporting their students with additional help on assignments? Where your students could go to “learn to learn” with study skills assistance, research training, other library resource guidance, and much more?

The Learning Commons was created to serve two primary functions:

First, it is a one-stop-shop for students’ academic needs – the Study Skills Center, the Research Center, and the Study Technology Center can all be found conveniently located in this one area. In between all these resources are tables and whiteboards set up to facilitate group work and collaboration.

The second function of the Learning Commons is to provide faculty members with a resource where they can send their students for further instruction. The main reference section of the Library has been relocated to the Learning Commons along with a number of computers, scanners, printers, group work areas and a copy machine. This collection of resources will be expanded to suit faculty and student needs in the coming years. The faculty’s use of this area and suggestions will help facilitate its growth and functions.

In a few years, the Learning Commons will no longer be confined to a small corner of the library. When the library remodel is complete, the Commons will become a main thoroughfare with all the academic resources a student could need. It will also be the site of research and development for new collaborative technologies. In the meantime, the current Commons can provide an exciting insight into the future of student learning and study.

Any suggestions for this area and how it can grow to support your academic needs would be greatly appreciated. Please forward any thoughts you have to coles@byui.edu.
